instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> high.
threads.message:
hi, this board came in with intermittent green light.
ppbus is 12.6v solid.
pp3v42 : 3.42v
i notice that I dont have smc bc acok when the green light is out.
I change isl, and then i got a fairly consistent green light.
when magsafe is plugged in, i got fan spin.
but theres no usb activity ( no mouse light, no caps lock, no chime).
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> voltage is 4.2v. any idea why its so high ? supposed to be 3.3v right.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> high.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is pulled-up to <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R5087</RESISTOR>).
Inspect <TRANSISTOR>Q5310</TRANSISTOR> area for corrosion; post its voltages.
Also check <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/01 and post voltages.
Test with known good DCIN board too.
